result.execSummary:
The defendant Daniel A. Scholze was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Disorderly Conduct [Modifiers: Domestic Abuse], a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
If Probation or Extended Supervision is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.
2 days of jail credit if revoked

miscConds.notes: PAYABLE DIRECTLY TO AND COLLECTED BY EAU CLAIRE COUNTY CLERK OF COURT.  NOT A CONDITION OF PROBATION.
No contact with R.M. unless she and agent approve
Any treatment/programming per agent including but not limited to Domestic Abuse Assessment.
AODA and follow through with recommendations

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Daniel A. Scholze

State objects.

Based on testimony, Court denies request of Defense.

Defendant appears with Attorney Gary Smith.
State by Ellen Anderson, ADA.
Defense requests to remove no contact condition from bond.
State did not receive a written motion- requests more time.
Bail Bond Hearing: 02/09/16 at 11:00 AM

Conditions:
No contact with R.M. (R.P.)
Defendant allowed to retrieve belongings if accompanied by a law enforcement officer.
Defendant not to consume/use/possess any illegal drugs or drug paraphernalia.
Defendant is to report to CTC within 24 hours for random/daily testing and/or programming.

Defendant appeared in custody via video conference from the jail without counsel and is advised of right to attorney.
